H0.text: The objects in constellations, which are patterns of objects seen in the night sky from Earth, are stars.

H1.text: The objects are planets, the celestial bodies that form constellations—patterns of objects seen in the night sky from Earth—and are like the Sun.

H2.text: The objects are located in this solar system, just as the Sun is.

H3.text: The objects heat the atmosphere of Earth, indicating that the objects in constellations are like the Sun.

A4.text: The 88 constellations recognized by the IAU as well as those by cultures throughout history are imagined figures and shapes derived from the patterns of stars in the observable sky.

A5.text: Stars in constellations can appear near each other in the sky, but they usually lie at a variety of distances away from the Earth.
